intro: Hamosa emoryana, commonly known as the Emory's hamosa, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its small, delicate white flowers and narrow, lance-shaped leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. Hamosa emoryana is often found in desert scrub and chaparral habitats, contributing to the biodiversity of these ecosystems.
